Learning Objectives

By the end of this unit, students will be able to:

  • Explain key MÄori economic concepts and values
  • Compare traditional MÄori and contemporary economic systems
  • Apply principles of manaakitanga (hospitality) and kaitiakitanga (guardianship) to financial decision-making
  • Analyze how MÄori economic principles can inform sustainable financial practices
  • Develop a personal financial plan incorporating MÄori values

Cultural Context: Tikanga MÄori in Economics

Traditional MÄori economic systems were based on reciprocal relationships and collective wellbeing rather than individual profit. Key concepts include:

MÄori Economic Values Matching Activity

Match each MÄori economic principle with its correct definition:

Term Definition
Utu Reciprocity - maintaining balance in exchanges
Manaakitanga Generosity and hospitality - enhancing others' mana
Kaitiakitanga Guardianship - sustainable resource management
Whanaungatanga Relationship building - economic connections
Tikanga Correct procedures - economic protocols

Tikanga Considerations: When discussing MÄori economic systems, remember these protocols:

  • Respect the mana (prestige) of traditional knowledge
  • Understand economic decisions were made collectively by hapÅ« (sub-tribe)
  • Recognize that resources were viewed as taonga (treasures) to be protected

Comparing Economic Systems

Economic System Comparison

Complete the table comparing aspects of traditional MÄori and contemporary economic systems:

Aspect Traditional MÄori System Contemporary System
Resource Ownership Collective (hapÅ«/iwi) Individual/Corporate
Primary Goal Community wellbeing Profit maximization
Time Horizon Intergenerational Short-term
Value Measurement Social and cultural capital Financial capital

Applying MÄori Economic Principles

Case Study: Sustainable Investment

Read this scenario and answer the questions:

"A MÄori land trust must decide between leasing land to a dairy corporation (high financial return but environmental impacts) or developing an organic community garden (lower financial return but sustainable and benefits community)."

Decision-Making Framework:

  1. How would kaitiakitanga influence this decision?
  2. What utu (balance) needs to be considered?
  3. How might manaakitanga apply to workers' conditions?
  4. What intergenerational impacts (whakapapa) should be considered?

Assessment Rubric

Criteria Achieved Merit Excellence
Understanding of MÄori economic principles Identifies basic concepts Explains concepts with examples Analyzes concepts in depth with cultural insight
Comparison of economic systems Lists some differences Compares systems with valid points Evaluates systems with critical analysis
Application to financial decisions Basic application of principles Clear application with reasoning Sophisticated application with innovation
Cultural authenticity Some cultural references Accurate cultural understanding Nuanced cultural insight and respect

Extension Activities

Personal Financial Plan

Create a personal financial plan incorporating MÄori economic principles:

Include kaitiakitanga in spending choices (eco-friendly products)
Apply manaakitanga in budgeting (charitable giving)
Consider whanaungatanga in income (supporting MÄori businesses)
Implement utu in savings (balance between present/future needs)

Research Project

Investigate a contemporary MÄori business or organization and analyze how it blends traditional economic principles with modern practices.

Teacher Implementation Notes

Prior Knowledge

Students should have basic understanding of:

  • Fundamental economic concepts (supply/demand, profit, etc.)
  • Key aspects of MÄori culture (concepts of mana, tapu, noa)
  • Basic financial literacy (budgeting, saving, investing)

Differentiation Strategies

  • Support: Provide vocabulary lists with definitions, use graphic organizers for comparisons
  • Extension: Have students research specific iwi economic models (e.g., Tainui's economic development)

Assessment Options

  • Written report comparing economic systems
  • Presentation on applying MÄori principles to a financial case study
  • Creation of a financial plan with MÄori values integration

Cultural Safety

  • Consult with local MÄori experts or kaumatua where possible
  • Use correct pronunciation of MÄori terms (provide audio if needed)
  • Acknowledge regional variations in MÄori economic practices

Resources and References

Recommended Readings

  • MÄori Economy Report - Te Puni KÅkiri
  • "Ka Hao te Rangatahi" - MÄori economic development strategies
  • "MÄori Values in the Modern Economy" - Journal of Indigenous Economics

Online Resources

  • Te Ara Encyclopedia - MÄori Economic History
  • MÄori Trustee financial literacy resources
  • Te PÅ«tea Matua (Reserve Bank) MÄori economic indicators

Community Connections

  • Local MÄori land trusts or incorporations
  • MÄori business networks (e.g., Federation of MÄori Authorities)
  • Iwi economic development units
